Module kivakit.kernel
Package com.telenav.kivakit.kernel.data.validation.validators

Class BaseValidator

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.telenav.kivakit.kernel.data.validation.validators.BaseValidator
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Validator
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ArgumentValidator, SwitchValidator
    public abstract class BaseValidator
extends java.lang.Object
implements Validator
    A base implementation of Validator that provides convenience methods for reporting validation issues:

    Validation Issue Reporting

    • fatal(String, Object...) - Reports a fatal validation failure, halting further progress via Ensure.fail(String, Object...)
    • problem(String, Object...) - Reports a non-fatal validation problem, causing data to be discarded but the process does not halt
    • quibble(String, Object...) - Reports a non-fatal and not very important validation problem where data is compromised but not discarded
    • warning(String, Object...) - Reports an issue that should ideally be corrected but is not fatal or a validation failure
    • fatalIf(boolean, String, Object...) - Conditionally reports a fatal problem
    • problemIf(boolean, String, Object...) - Conditionally reports a problem
    • quibbleIf(boolean, String, Object...) - Conditionally reports a quibble
    • warningIf(boolean, String, Object...) - Conditionally reports a warning
    The base validator also assists in running other validators (validate(Validator), such as validators from Validatable parent classes. The problem and warning methods make use of the variable argument formatting as defined by MessageFormatter in Problem and Warning. To use this class, you need only implement onValidate().

    Example Validator

    This is roughly the validation method for Place: 

     public Validator validator(final ValidationType type)
 {
     return new BaseValidator()
     {
         protected void onValidate()
         {
             // Ensure the superclass
             validate(Place.super.validator(type));

             // then check for other problems
             problemIf(location() == null, "Location is missing");
             problemIf(isEmpty(name()), "Name is empty");
             problemIf(type() == null, "TimeFormat is missing");
             problemIf(isZero(population()), "Population is missing or zero");
         }
     };
 }
    Validation Results

    Once validation has occurred, the method isInvalid() can be called to determine if any problems or quibbles (which are both are considered invalidating while warnings are not) were broadcast during the (possibly nested) validation process. The state of isInvalid() is used as the return value of Validator.validate() when the validator is used.

    Subclasses of BaseValidator may be used to decorate problem reports with additional details by overriding the problem(String, Object...) and warning(String, Object...) methods.

    Implementation Note

    Validation is a recursive, re-entrant process because validators can call other validators. One possible way to propagate the status of validation would be to have a call chain of validators, each returning its status to the prior level. This method results in a lot of boiler plate code creating and checking status objects. A cleaner option, used here, is to keep thread-local statistics during validation and manage nested re-entry with ReentrancyTracker.

    Using a reentrancy tracker, thread-local statistics are reset only on the first entrance of a thread to perform a validation operation. This allows statistics to accumulate during validation so that the final exit can inspect the cumulative results of all sub-validations to see if the whole operation has ended in failure or not.

    Status-by-step comments that detail this approach are validate(Listener) below.

    Author:
    jonathanl (shibo)
    See Also:
    Ensure, Validator, Problem, Quibble, Warning, ReentrancyTracker, ThreadLocal

        public final boolean validate​(Listener listener)
